A B S T R A C T
Liquid metal is a liquid-state metallic material with a low melting point at or around room temperature. Owing to their high thermal or electrical conductivity, low viscosity and superior fluidity, liquid metals are emerging as a highly desirable candidate in a broad array of areas, such as flexible electronics, thermal management, soft machines and biomedical materials. However, bulk liquid metal is not readily utilized because of its high surface tension and large dimension-induced dexterity limitations. To address this challenge, liquid metals have been innovated with micro/nanotechnology to endow the bulk liquid metals with remarkably diversified performances. These new functional materials not only possess the softness of classical liquid metals but also have many outstanding properties, including great thermal conductivity, self-healing ability and stimuli-responsive deformability. Compared to rigid inorganic micro/nanoscale materials, soft liquid metal micro/nanoparticles demonstrate their unconventionally superior flexibility, compliance and tunability. This review is dedicated to summarize the state-of-the-art progress in fabricating methods, highlight unique features, and discuss applications of liquid metal micro/nanoparticles in biomedicine, soft electronics, thermal management and soft motors. Future outlooks, including both opportunities and scientific challenges of liquid metal micro/nanoparticles, are also presented here.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Low-melting liquid metals (LMs) are a unique family of metals that behave like liquids around room temperature. They stay in a liquid-like state and possess both metallic and amorphous properties that belong to solid metals and water-like fluids [1,2]. This kind of material refers to pure metals and their alloys compounded with other elements that help to decrease the melting point. Generally, five metal elements can be defined as low-melting LMs: francium (Fr, ˜27°C), caesium (Cs, 28.40°C), rubidium (Rb, 38.89°C), mercury (Hg, -39°C) and gallium (Ga, 29.8°C) [3]. As emerging functional materials, Ga-based LMs not
only retain basic metallic characteristics, including high thermal conductivity and good electrical conductivity, but also exhibit superb fluidity, excellent flexibility and low viscosity. For example, the viscosity of eutectic gallium-indium (EGaIn) is just twice that of water at 20°C, which is unexpected according to the common knowledge of stagnant solid-state metals [4]. Importantly, EGaIn is less toxic and nonvolatile compared to Hg and shows no radioactivity compared to Rb, Cs or Fr [5,6]. Additionally, the high chemical stability of EGaIn ensures its harmlessness and high biocompatibility.

Different from other aforementioned potential room-temperature LMs, Ga and its alloys play an increasingly considerable role in a variety of promising applications, such as biomedicine [1,9–11] (including bone substitute, nerve reconnection, high-contrast imaging, drug delivery and tumour therapy), soft and flexible electronics [12–18] (including soft circuits, 3D printing, self-healing materials, reconfigurable electric components and functional electronic devices), enhanced heat transfer [19–23] (including high thermal conductivity coolants, multifunctional interface materials and phase-change materials) and soft machines (including self-fuelled motors).
Although Ga-based LMs show low toxicity, the relatively limited degradability and hard control of a considerable dose of bulk LM still impedes its utilization in various applications. One typical example is that macroscopic LMs cannot be utilized very well as drug carriers with targeting function [9,24,25]. However, liquid metal micro/nanoparticles (LMPs) are more suitable for such applications because their small size and dose greatly reduce the toxicity to the human body and intrinsic stimulus responsiveness to the internal microenvironment. In addition, the thiol-LM interaction promotes the multi-functionalization of LMPs as a desired drug-loading matrix and effective targeting medium, which are usually preferred to achieve ideal therapeutic performance [26].
In terms of thermal management, the inherent limitations of macroscopic LM could also be offset by using LMPs. Since 2002, Liu’s group and other researchers have been continuously improving LM thermal management technologies [27–37]. During the past decade, many brand techniques, such as LM-combined cooling and novel materials, LM-based phase change materials and LM-based thermal interface materials, have been proposed in this area. However, when applied in chip cooling, the high electrical conductivity of thermal interface materials is undesirable in electronic packaging due to possible electrical leakage in high power devices. The homogeneity of LMPs suspended in insulated substrates may solve this problem because it keeps them from precipitating and regaining thermal conductivity.
Additionally, scaling down the physical size of LMs is critical for printed electronics. LM inks, a promising candidate for manufacturing soft and flexible printed electronics, have already shown advantages such as high conductivity, deformability, robustness, softness and stretchability. Nevertheless, circuits fabricated with macroscopic LMs also endow high-integration microelectronics with relatively low resolution. Sintering enables conductive traces consisting of LMPs to effectively improve the resolution of constructed circuits compared with bulk LMs. The utilization of the sintered LMPs may also solve the problem of incompatibility with inkjet printing.
Many studies have demonstrated that by manipulating the thin oxide layer covering the LM droplets by electrochemical [38,39], photochemical [40], hydrodynamic [41], or magnetic [42] methods, the physicochemical properties of the surface could be altered to change their dynamic behaviour; hence, an LM-based soft robot could be fabricated. In addition, self-propulsion and rotation behaviours are also observed for sub-millimetre LMs. Normally, when the particle has a smaller size, the regulation of its movement behaviours is more convenient in the presence of lower-power external stimuli. Thus, LMPbased soft robots are becoming a rather promising area. Additionally, LMP materials are available to address topics for which bulk LMs are not suitable. These topics cover areas such as anticancer drug delivery [24–26], thermal interface materials, high-resolution soft electronics [43–47], and mcro/nanoscale soft motors [44,48]. It is believed that combining micro/nanotechnology with LMs can significantly broaden the applications in the above fields (Fig. 1).
Although bulk LM has widely penetrated into practical applications, the utilization of LMPs has just started. The differences between bulk LMs and LMPs are compared detailed in Table 1. Similar to other micro/nanomaterials, a great barrier confronting the widespread use of LMPs is either its poor homogeneity or complexity of preparation
[52,53]. Fluidity, transformability, softness, oxidation features and other properties could be inherited by LMPs. In addition, LMPs also possess some unexpected size-dependent characteristics, including multifunctional accessibility, self-healing, and stimuli-responsive deformability, according to the specific needs and corresponding treatments.
Notably, soft LMPs also show a great advantage compared to rigid micro/nanoscale materials (Fig. 2). Rigid particles are not easily dispersed in substrates, and this usually leads to blockage for practical systems. Additionally, mechanical friction resulting from rigid micro/ nanoparticles can induce injury to soft substrates. In contrast, flexible LMPs show high flexibility and compliance, which are excellent prospects for highly versatile materials. In particular, natural physicochemical properties of LMPs enable their deformation to be converted between different shapes under specific conditions. Hybrid structures can also be achieved by synthesizing solid-liquid coexistence LMP materials. The easy attachment of LMPs to various substrates further broadens the applications of high-performance LMs. Briefly, LMP-based soft transformers have a number of novel applications that cannot be accomplished with rigid materials.
In this paper, we will comprehensively focus on different fabrication methods and physicochemical characteristics of LMPs. In particular, we would highlight the applications of these transformable and soft micro/ nanoscale materials. Furthermore, unsolved scientific challenges and the promising future of these emerging materials are also discussed.

sections.heading: 2. Physicochemical characteristics of LMPs
sections.text: Physicochemical characteristics are of great concern in micro/nanomaterials, especially for metal candidates [54]. Hence, significant differences arise in major features when scattering bulk LMs into liquid metal microparticles (LMMPs) or liquid metal nanoparticles (LMNPs).

sections.heading: 2.1. Morphology
sections.text:
There are multiple methods to fabricate LMPs. All these methods of preparing bulk LMs towards LMPs are discussed in detail in Section 3. Research has shown that the initial particle size distribution of different fabricating methods differs from tens of nanometres to hundreds of micrometres. Among them, LMPs always form regular spherical shapes. According to the mechanism of decreasing surface energy, the resultant particles were mostly sphere because of the enormous surface tension of Ga-based LM (approximately 600mN/m, which is 9 times larger than that of water), which prompted these extremely small particles to minimize surface area to maintain stability. LMP spheres in a wide size range from tens of nanometres to several hundred micrometres are displayed in Fig. 3A. However, the spherical particles could also transform into rod-shaped composites of gallium oxide monohydroxide ((GaO)OH), as shown in Fig. 3B.
In addition to size and shape, surface morphology of the LMPs was also investigated. Observed by Zhang et al., a dense distribution of nanoplatelets with an average length and width of 200 nm and 50 nm, respectively, were arranged on the surface of sonicated LM spheres when increasing the sonication duration to 10min. With further increase in sonication duration (20min), both the amount and the dimension of such nanoplatelets tended to become greater (Fig. 3C). Finally, the nanoplatelets detached from the LM sphere surfaces when the sonication time reached 60min. The mechanism behind this morphological transformation phenomenon is the repeated process of formation and removal of the surface oxide layer.
To form a highly homogeneous LMP suspension with controllable size distribution and smooth surface, intermolecular forces that enabled self-assembly behaviour were introduced by adding a surfactant. Once the bulk LM is ultrasonically dispersed, fast organic matter assembles on the LM interface. The addition of the surfactant prevents individual spheres from recoalescing, thereby reducing the ultimate size
distribution and improving the uniformity of dispersed particles.

sections.heading: 2.2. Oxidisability
sections.text:
Liquid-state Ga and its alloy are homogenously covered by a thin native oxide layer because Ga can be readily oxidized when exposed to ambient air or neutral aqueous solution, and there is no exception for LMPs. Electrical and thermal conductivity and wettability properties may change when oxidation occurs; hence, it is a facile method to modify the physicochemical features of LMPs.
To reveal the oxidation mechanism, experiments have been carried out to study the gradual formation process of Ga oxide. For the particles formed in water, small crystallites identified as (GaO)OH on the surface acted as an isolated layer against recombining into bulk gallium. In the presence of oxygen and decomposed OH−, crystallites of (GaO)OH would be formed, and the overall (GaO)OH formation could be summarized as follows:
2Ga+2OH−+O2→2(GaO)OH (1)
The image of the gradual growth of oxygen-induced (GaO)OH crystallites is shown in Fig. 4A. Similarly, the formation of (GaO)OH nanorods could also be performed with LMPs by sonication under thermal treatment due to the reactivity of Ga. For LMPs dispersed in surfactant solution, fast organic matter self-assembly at the interface of particles protects the material from further oxidation and thus could sustain a regular sphere shape. As shown in Fig. 4B, the inner and outer shells of these particles were ˜3 nm thick and ˜2 nm thick, respectively. The organic coating surrounded the gallium oxide (Ga2O3), serving as a spherical protective shell that not only facilitated control of the particle size but also guaranteed that LMPs were structurally stable against amalgamation [57].
In addition, the oxide layer introduced engineering flexibility with
tuneable shape, size distribution, and physical and chemical properties, which could enable the on-demand design of nanorobots. One significant application of nanorobots is to deliver drugs. It has been found that thiolated ligands surrounding an oxide layer could be used as surface conjugation sites for theranostic agents. Lu et al. synthesized multifunctional bio-conjugated LM medicine through simply applying ultrasonication [26]. The two ligands used here were thiolated (2-hydroxypropyl)-b-cyclodextrin (designated MUA-CD) and thiolated hyaluronic acid (designated m-HA). They not only capped the LM core during the formation of nanospheres but also served as a drug carrier and targeting moiety separately. This bioconjugation mechanism triggered external manipulating methods that can aid in creating miniscule machines employed in human physiological environments. Remote manipulation of bulk LM remains a major impediment; however, actuating LMPs via diversified modifications on its surface can be readily achieved.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrical properties
sections.text:
Liquid metal alloys with high electrical conductivity and intrinsically soft characteristics make them desirable for flexible electronics. Nevertheless, for LMPs, the oxide shell of Ga2O3 has a special semi-conductive feature and precludes the particles from coalescing in the conductive pathway [57].
Deposited LMPs are separated; thus, LM films formed from them are non-conductive. However, external stimuli could coalesce the LMPs into a continuous liquid phase, and high conductivity is achieved. The morphological differences between the coalescence and non-coalescence particles are displayed in Fig. 5A. As shown in Fig. 5B, experiments were carried out to determine the conductive properties of the LMPs. A high breakdown field of ˜50 kVm−1 was observed through two-probe measurement, indicating an EGaIn nanoparticle network as
an electrical insulator prior to coalescence [46]. After selectively tapping, a continuous liquid phase film appeared readily, and a relatively low electrical resistivity (0.0010 Ω·cm) and high conductivity (9.6× 102 S/cm) were measured around the coalesced region. Based on these series of tests, sintering, which means wiping off the oxide layer and inducing the LM particles from non-coalescence to coalescence, is able to alter LMP electrical features from nonconductive to conductive. Several methods have been adopted to achieve sintering methods, such as laser sintering [59], mechanical sintering [46] and peeling off [60]. These methods will be discussed in detail in Section 4.2. There was no doubt that simple methods, such as mechanical sintering and peeling off, enabled the rupture of the oxide layer to achieve a conductive pathway.
In certain cases, LMNPs are more desirable because of their ability
to form high-resolution patterns. To enhance the reconfiguration efficiency of LMNPs through mechanical mechanism-mediated sintering approaches, further studies aimed at searching suitable mechanical pressure for the activation of electrical conductivity with respect to particle diameters have been conducted. For example, Lear et al. developed a relationship between particle size and the required force for sintering using data from experiments carried out by atomic force microscopy (AFM), as shown in Fig. 5C. The electrical response of particle films was assessed via mechanical compression, validating a threshold force at which sintering may be achieved according to a certain diameter, and a linear correlation between particle size and rupture force was derived [61].
In addition, the Ga2O3 shell endows these particles with regulable dielectric properties [62]. For example, by tuning the composition of GaInSn alloys, the highest superconducting critical temperature could be adjusted to as high as 6.6 K (compared with 1.08 K for Ga). This novel superconducting material may promote the development of highspeed microelectronics [48].

sections.heading: 2.4. Thermal properties
sections.text:
Low melting point is a unique property of room-temperature LMs, together with high boiling temperature, providing a wide temperature range (8–2200 °C) in the liquid phase. The melting point of diverse LM materials generally depends on the alloying elements and particle size. Particle size significantly influences melting point, and the formed nanoparticles are much smaller than bulk metal materials [59].
To study the effect of particle size on thermal properties, Kumar et al. reported calorimetry measurement results aimed at studying the thermal properties of micro/nanoparticles in comparison with bulk Ga [63]. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) results showed that the melting point for bulk Ga was approximately 29.8 °C. As shown in Fig. 6A, an approximate 1 K (27.9 °C) decrease was observed for Ga microparticles with diameters larger than 0.45 μm, whereas the melting point of Ga nanoparticles with diameters of 35 nm decreased to −14.2 °C (Fig. 6B). Similarly, the freezing points were shown to decrease to −21 °C and −128.3 °C, respectively. Notably, when the melting point is reversible and small Ga particles change back into bulk Ga after being heated (dashed black line in Fig. 6B), the melting point returns to 29.1 °C, which is similar to that of bulk Ga, as shown in Fig. 6A.
In addition to melting point, thermal conductivity and thermal interface resistance are also widely used to assess the heat conduction/ dissipation performance of low-melting point liquid metals. The thermal conductivity of bulk Ga is approximately 29.28W/(m K), which is almost 50 times higher than that of water (0.599W/(m K)), implying its great potential to dissipate heat. However, the thermal conductivity of bulk LM decreases to approximately 13.07W/(m K) in the presence of a thin layer of gallium oxide. sections.heading: 2.5. Transformability
sections.text:
Since the discovery of external electric field-induced macroscopic LM configurable transformations, a number of methods for manipulating controllable shape changes have been proposed, such as electrochemical, ionic imbalance, and electromagnetic reactions. Regardless of the methods used, the mechanism underlying the
transformation behaviours could be attributed to changes in the electrical double layer forming on the surface of liquid droplets. Once the charge symmetry was broken, the surface tension was altered to result in a differential pressure, thus promoting LM to deform.
As for separated LMPs, the manipulating mechanism seems to be different, mainly depending on their reactions with the surrounding environment. Transformations including separation, coalescence and shape change still occur when influenced by external stimulation (Fig. 7A). These unique transformation behaviours make LMPs desirable in drug delivery and release. For example, Lu at al. investigated the role of a pH-responsive LM-based carrier in the delivery of an anticancer drug, doxorubicin (Dox). Their results indicated that the LMNPs loaded with Dox with an average diameter of 107 nm could gradually aggregate and subsequently degrade in HeLa cells incubated for 1 h under acidic conditions (Fig. 7B), proving that altering the pH in a
physiological environment could readily achieve the coalescence of the LMNPs [26]. Moreover, Lu et al. discovered that nanospheres coated with graphene quantum dots (GQDs) could absorb and convert photoenergy to impel the morphological transformation of the inner LM core. Fig. 7C shows the transformation process of the nanospheres under irradiation (at a power density of 100mW/cm2 with 635 nm as the irradiation wavelength for up to 20min) [25]. Therefore, this series of morphology transformations proves that both heat and light irradiation are valid for driving the simultaneous phase separation and morphological transformation of the LM segments. The transformation ability of LM particles increases the diversity of available LMP forms and provides an unprecedented opportunity for advanced drug delivery.

sections.heading: 2.6. Self-healing feature
sections.text:
Self-healing materials facilitate the autonomous maintenance of electronic components, which help improve advanced electronic packaging. Due to the high conductivity of LMs and spontaneously formed oxide layers preventing inner fluid-like cores from leaking out and unintentionally dispersing, LMs, particularly Ga-based ones, have proven their capacity as self-healing agents in practical applications, such as circuit wires [18], antennas [59,65]. LMMPs are normally utilized as inclusions in these applications. Once mechanical failure occurs, the shape-retaining structure (e.g., microcapsule coating generally made out of polymer) of LMs ruptures and allows internal LMs to
coalesce into the conductive pathway through the broken sites, which result in subsequent mechanic and electronic capacity restoration [18]. In addition, Markvicka et al. revealed that LM particles suspended in a soft elastomer spontaneously rupture to reform connections with adjacent particles and re-route conductive pathways when damaged.
Besides, benefiting from fluidity and surface tension, LMs based material is one of the best candidates to produce lithium-ion battery (LIB) anode as self-healing material. As is known to all, the anode fabricated by lithium-active material suffers from the uneven stress distribution according to the volume expansion/shrinkage during the charge/discharge cycles of LIB, probably causing the mechanical damage, finally resulting in mechanical and electrical invalidation of LIB. Ga based alloy is uniquely interesting as anode material due to its very low melting point and Li-active nature. The melting-point of Ga is 29.8 °C, alloying with other metal decrease this number. One Ga atom can host two Li atoms upon full lithiation, delivering a theoretical capacity of 769mA h/g by forming Li2Ga alloy, which makes Ga a Liactive material as well. Taking advantage from both of the characters, a new Ga-Sn LMP, stabilized in a reduced graphene oxide (RGO)/carbon nanotube (CNT) skeleton, as a room-temperature self-healing anode for LIB was proposed. This kind of anode material could realize the selfhealing function through resisting the volume expansion/contraction of anode surface during charge/discharge cycles, leading to an improved capacity performance and ultra-long cycle life [66].

sections.heading: 3. Fabrication methods of LMPs
sections.text: There generally exist two kinds of techniques for the preparation of micro/nanoparticles: top-down and bottom-up methods. In terms of LMs, top-down processes through physical split interactions, including moulding, fluidic jetting, flow-focusing, shearing liquids into complex particles (SLICE) and sonication, are much more commonly used to fabricate LMMPs and LMNPs. Additionally, the bottom-up method, which mainly refers to physical vapor deposition (PVD) at the atomic level, has attracted increasing attention in recent years. Six fabrication methods are illustrated in Fig. 8 according to the average size of particles. In the following section, the pros and cons of these fabrication methods are discussed in detail.

sections.heading: 3.1. Moulding
sections.text:
The moulding technique could prepare micro-LM spheres within a wide diameter range from hundreds of microns to several millimetres. Fig. 9A depicts the steps for producing EGaIn microspheres: a laser cutter patterns pillars on an acrylic sheet, and then polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) is poured and solidified over the acrylic sheet to form a soft and flexible lid consisting of many voids. Next, those voids are filled with LMPs by spreading bulk LM over them. Owing to the offset effect of the thin oxide layer against surface tension, the obtained particles could not be regular spheres. However, filling the lid with hydrochloric acid vapor could help to remove the oxide skin. These spheres can either be harvested individually or transferred to
another substrate readily (Fig. 9B) [67]. Although moulding is a facile way and the dimensions of LMMPs can be controlled with a designed mould, mass production is time-consuming, and fabrication of microparticles with various diameters is not scalable.

sections.heading: 3.2. Fluidic jetting
sections.text:
The fluid-jetting device is simple and easy to set up. It only requires
a syringe and a petri dish to prepare LMMPs at room temperature (Fig. 9C). After the LMs are injected into an aqueous solution mixed with the surfactant, a continuous thin stream appears and is subsequently broken into various shapes, including the neck, shuttle, irregular and spherical, depending on the increase in distance away from the pinhead (Fig. 9D). Finally, LMMPs with an average diameter of 313 ± 34 μm could be generated. It should be noted that the protective effect of the surfactant and oxide layer keeps the LMMPs monodisperse
and stable (Fig. 9E and F). If the temperature drops below the melting point of the LMs, the LMMPs will solidify and form porous metal blocks with microstructures [68].
In addition, altering the bore diameters of pinheads and the jetting velocity could be used as valid ways to tune the diameters of LMMPs; that is to say, both the smaller pinheads and higher velocity will contribute to more intimate LMMPs. For example, the mean particle diameter fabricated using a 60 μm pinhead is 590 ± 71 μm. When the diameter of the pinhead decreases to 41 μm, the average droplet diameter could reach 173 ± 18 μm. Such method is convenient and yet efficient and relatively inexpensive, and it has been widely used in fabricating LM micromotors [72,73]. However, one major restriction for practical applications is the wide polydispersity of particle size.

sections.heading: 3.3. Microfluidic flow-focusing
sections.text:
To obtain homogeneous LMMPs, a microfluidic flow-focusing device forces both LMs and another fluid (glycerol and/or water) that is immiscible with LMs to pass through a microchannel. When two streams meet in a micro-orifice, the continuous-phase fluid (glycerol and/or water) generates sufficient shear force to break up the dispersed-phase LMs into LMMPs and combine to impel the LMMPs out of the flowfocusing device (Fig. 10A) [69,70]. Finally, a mixed system of LMMPs together with glycerine and water is formed. To separate LMMPs from glycerol, Gol et al. designed a transfer system to realize the hydrodynamic transfer of LMMPs to a sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution (Fig. 10B). As demonstrated in Fig. 10C, when the confluence of LMMPs, NaOH and glycerol emerges, LMMPs gradually transit across the interface from high-viscosity flow (glycerol) into the NaOH flow with low viscosity [74].
The sizes of particles produced by the microfluidic technique depend on three main factors: interfacial tension, inertial force, and shear force. However, once the microfluidics device is fixed, the regulation of the experimental conditions to tune the size of the microdroplets is difficult, which means that a conventional flow-focusing device could only produce specific particles that match the associated microchannel dimensionally. To address this problem, Tang et al. developed an innovative flow-focusing device that could alter LM surface tension (i.e., interfacial tension) by using both the effects of electrochemistry and electrocapillarity (Fig. 10D). As a result, the distribution of diameter and the frequency of formation of LM microdroplets could be regulated. As the voltage increased from 0 V to 10 V, the diameter of the LM droplets diminished smoothly from ˜185 μm to ˜85 μm, and the yield of the microdroplets increased dramatically (Fig. 10E) [75]. However, reducing interfacial tension is not enough to accomplish the transition of particle size from microscale to nanoscale. To further reduce the mean size of LMPs via the microfluidic flow-focusing technique, Tang et al. designed a microfluidic chip to fabricate LMNPs with the help of high shear force induced by ultrasonic acoustic waves. This chip contains a serpentine-shaped channel whose inlet includes a T-junction (with a height and width of 50 and 500 μm, respectively) as the outlet. Bonate-functionalized brushed polyethylene glycol is selected as a continuous-phase fluid, which could minimize viscosity effects that may inhibit the separation of LMs from T-junctions. When brushed polyethylene glycol flows through the T-junction, LMMPs will be produced and later gradually broken into nanoparticles in the presence of ultrasound when travelling along the microchannel (Fig. 10F). Notably, the average size of the particles can be adjusted by changing the width and length of the flow channel. As shown in Fig. 10G and H, tuning width will influence the uniformity of particle size, and the average size was reduced from ˜400 to ˜450 nm when channel length was increased from 10 to 100mm [76].
Superior to moulding and fluidic jetting, flow-focusing methods could provide a continuous way to produce monodisperse LMMPs/ LMNPs with tuneable sizes. However, these complex devices are easily consumed and are complicated to manufacture.

sections.heading: 3.4. SLICE
sections.text:
SLICE, a direct way to synthesize soft micro/nanoparticles, serves as an extension of the conventional emulsification technique. A pertinent fabrication process is revealed in Fig. 11A. LMs and carrier liquids can maintain a thin, inert coating layer on the surface of LMPs to inhibit solidification and are directly added into the blender. Next, shear force generated by the shearing implement assists in the formation of supernatant that contains LMPs (Fig. 11B) from 6.4 nm to over 10 μm in diameter [77]. With the SLICE approach to particle synthesis, forces acting on a droplet include the following: shear (γ), gravity (Fg), drag (Fd), centrifugal forces (Fc), and buoyancy (Fb), a minor contributor due to density differences (Fig. 11C). Dominated by γ, the initial static droplet is stretched into a cylinder-like shape as the rotation speed gradually increases. When reaching the Rayleigh−Plateau limit (where radius rdroplet > 1.5 rcylinder), the cylindrical LM breaks into LMPs.
Notably, SLICE is a simple method for synthesizing core-shell particles with complex surface compositions and morphologies. Applying fluidic shear force provides a tuneable, low-cost, green, and facile approach to create micro/nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 11D and E, the diameters of particles fabricated by SLICE ranges from nanometre to micrometre in scale. SLICE is not a straightforward technique to fabricate a mass of nanoparticles with a homogeneous size distribution due to the asymmetry of the shear forces, which limits application with requirements for periodic structures.

sections.heading: 3.5. Sonication
sections.text:
An immiscible liquid system will occur after adding LM into water or organic solvents. When a sonication probe is introduced into this system, the ultrasonic energy generated from the probe will induce acoustic cavitation in water or organic solvents, further induce bulk LM transformation into LMMPs and finally cause dispersion of the molten LMNPs (Fig. 12A and B) [48,58,71,78–80]. Under sonication, the change in particle size is accompanied by variations in output power, sonication time and temperature. For example, a lower temperature usually leads to smaller particles (Fig. 12C), and the mean diameter of particles synthesized by sonication at 50 ℃ (60 nm) is approximately 1.7-fold that at 20 ℃ (35 nm). Moreover, the reversible coalescence and break-up behaviour of LMPs could be adjusted by adding an acid solution to remove the oxidation film or changing the temperature between 20 and 50°C, which does not occur at a constant temperature of approximately 20°C, even when the same metred acid was added (Fig. 12E). In addition, with the increases in sonication time and output power, the average diameter and the time to reach minimum size level decrease separately. It is impossible to reduce the size of the nanoparticle over an infinite range, and 35 nm is approximately the minimum size obtained by the sonication method (Fig. 12D) [64].
Notably, if the immiscible liquid system lacks surfactants, the oxide layer on the particle surface will be gradually detached by the applied ultrasound energy; meanwhile, the freshly exposed surface of Ga droplets will be oxidized rapidly to establish a new Ga3O3 layer. This repetitive process will greatly assist in transforming Ga into Ga2O3, presenting the morphological change from nano-spherical particles to suspended nanoflake-like Ga oxides. (Fig. 12F) [6,81]. Interestingly, LMNPs could also realize a three-dimensional shape change from sphere to rod by the addition of oxidizing agent, such as GQD [24], positively-charged cetyltrimethylammonium bromide [82] or melanin nanoparticles [83]. Specifically, after the addition of those oxidizing agent, LMNPs will be oxidized and transform into nanosheets under sonication. But the resulting nanosheets are (GaO)OH rather than Ga2O3. Then, these nanosheets will roll up spontaneously to nanorods [24]. Recently, Gu et al. found that regulating reaction parameters, such as sonication time and temperature has an important influence on the formation process of nanorod [83].
It seems that stability is closely related to two factors: oxide layer
and surfactant. In fact, the mechanisms behind protecting particles against fusion and coalescence are not fully understood but appear to strongly involve the protection of these two factors. Covering the oxide layer on surfaces and adding a surfactant into a solution to ensure stable
dispersion have become two of the most commonly used methods. Generally, the oxide layer is strong enough to cope with aggregation driven by surface tension, which briefly guarantees stable dispersion of LMPs in neutral solution. However, if the oxide film is dissolved or
stripped off constantly, the balance between dispersal particles will be quickly broken, which further induces the coalescence or fusion of particles. Unfortunately, the thin oxide layer will be dissolved rapidly when pH rises or falls. Moreover, Kurtjak et al. proved that the degradation process of the oxidation layer can occur even in neutral solutions in the presence of a mechanical force, and 1/3 of the contained Ga is released as Ga3+ ions after 34 h of shaking at 37 °C with an orbital rate of 337 rpm [84]. Hence, particles can remain steady for a long time in acidic or alkaline environments only with the help of surfactants that should be first added into the immiscible liquid system before sonication, such as alcohol, 1-dodecanethiol [85], and thiol-based surfactants [52]. In previous reports, thiol-based surfactants, especially mercaptooctadecane (C18H37-SH), were found to be effective not only in stabilizing LMNPs but also in improving the yield of nanoparticles. Among thiol-based surfactants, C18H37-SH exhibits the highest efficiency in yielding particles, simultaneously facilitating the production of smaller LMPs (80 nm) (Fig. 12G and H).
The control of particle size and shape is essential because of the strong correlation between structure and performance. Thus, because it stabilizes and regulates LMPs, ultrasound sonication is currently the most commonly used method to mass-produce LMNPs. How to further obtain smaller LMNPs (such as those less than 10 nm) with sonication is worth further investigation.

sections.heading: 3.6. PVD
sections.text:
The bottom-up method is a new emerging method utilizing the PVD technique to fabricate LMNPs. The fabrication process of EGaIn nanoparticles is an example (Fig. 13A and B). Overall, bulk EGaIn placed within a tungsten boat is vaporized into atoms under electric resistance heating. These atoms subsequently diffuse towards and collide with each other to form stable nuclei on a cold target substrate (silicon, glass or mica), while a number of atoms are nucleating and merging. Then, the EGaIn nuclei further grow by collecting adatoms and atoms surrounding the nucleation site. LMPs grow gradually in this process. At the first 100 s, the average particle size is approximately 25 nm (almost the smallest average size). Further increasing the deposition time to 500 s results in the fusion of EGaIn particles to larger than 100 nm and a clear particle size separation (Fig. 13C and D). These nanoparticles are monodisperse and can remain stable in the absence of surfactants [86]. It has been known that particle stability highly depends on the function of surfactants, and omitting them may cause the aggregates to fuse and coalesce, but the electrical or thermal properties of the pristine LMNPs
will be modestly affected in the absence of the surfactants. However, due to the high vapor pressure and superior boiling temperature of EGaIn, PVD is difficult to perform, and whether the bottom-up method could earn practical applications is unrevealed.
A summary of the above fabrication methods is listed in Table 2.
4. Applications in multiple fields
Increasing the specific surface area and scaling down the physical sizes of LMPs is critical for special applications in areas such as biomedicine, soft electronics, thermal management and self-fuelled motors. Additionally, micro/nanoscale LM composite materials significantly change and improve physical, chemical, and biological properties, which are important in fabricating self-healing materials, interface materials and soft wearable devices. Small LM-based soft transformers have a number of novel applications that cannot be achieved with bulk materials. For example, the toxicity of bulk LMs could not be ignored, whereas that of a small dose of LMMPs/LMNPs in the human body is considered useful and harmless. Although the potential practical applications of patterning bulk LMs have been shown through direct writing and microchannel injecting, the need for fabricating more precise soft circuit boards with higher resolution still remains. Fortunately, significant advances in the preparation of micro/ nanomaterials could help to overcome these obstacles, enabling relevant practical applications by introducing LMPs. Compared with that of bulk LMs, the transformation of LMNPs could be much more readily achieved by manual manipulation.
Fig. 14 presents the schematic of modified LMPs and corresponding applications. The surface of LMNPs are easily coated with ligands that could be served as the drug-loading matrix. Those LMNPs could be able to trigger drug release under mildly acidic cellular conditions [26]. Besides, the surface of LMNPs also could assemble with graphene quantum dots, and those LMMPs could be transformed into nanorods to promote the complete destruction of tumour cell endosomes upon exposure to light [24]. Additionally, the synthesis of LM nanorods can also be achieved by the incorporation of positively-charged surfactant or melanin nanoparticles [82,83]. Besides, inkjet patterning of colloidal suspensions of LMs droplets with externally applied mechanical sintering can achieve high-resolution printed electronics. To overcome mechanical failure caused by external force or rapidly increased power density, LMPs could spontaneously recover the broken point with the help of self-healing feature [44]. For example, once crack damage interrupts the conductive pathway, LMMPs covered with a polymeric
(caption on next page)
urea-formaldehyde shell wall will release the interior LMs to repair the broken path [88]. In term of thermal management, LMPs with super thermal properties play an important role in the next generation thermal interface materials (TIMs). LMMPs that could easily realize transformation and merging are suitable for transformable and soft TIMs. Moreover, the insulative surfactants layer coating on the surface of LMNPs has a negligible influence on heat transfer but hinders the transmission of electrons [89]. Thus, those LMNPs are promising candidates for insulative but heat-conducting TIMs. When exposed to alkaline environment, the electrical characteristic on surface of LMMPs changes and electrical double layer (EDL) that is a critical element for motor’s driving and regulation occurs [90]. An asymmetrical EDL induced by external field could lead to the deformation of particles and further push motors forward [91]. Apart from characteristics listed above, LMPs also have a number of advantages that are desirable for practical applications. Thus, an overall description of the applications of LMPs in biomedicine, soft electronics, thermal management, and transformable motors are systematically presented in this section.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Anticancer therapy
sections.text:
Many properties of LMNPs, such as low toxicity, enhanced permeating and retention (EPR) effects, photothermal conversion, easy modification and deformability, make them novel materials that can combine chemotherapy with physical therapy in cancer treatments [1]. Functional LMNPs are capable of accumulating at the tumour site through EPR effects or other active targeting. Upon external laser irradiation, certain LMNPs aggregate and further block local vessels to cut off the blood supply of the tumour while converting laser energy to heat to kill tumour cells. For other LMNPs that performed as drug
cargos, they could enter cancer cells via endocytosis and puncture the lysosome membrane through the deformation of LMNPs to accelerate the release of drugs.
In the following sections, the three important directions of LMNPs in cancer treatment will be discussed: 1) Biodegradable drug carriers for controllable drug delivery; 2) Intelligent shape transformers to destroy endosomes/lysosomes; and 3) Effective sensitizers in photothermal therapy.

sections.heading: 4.1.1.1. Biodegradable drug carriers for controllable drug
sections.text:
delivery. Inorganic soft nanoparticles with novel physical characteristics have enabled drug carriers with more flexibility and adaptability. In addition, LMNPs have shown evident advantages of biodegradation in a mild acid cellular microenvironment. Lu et al. synthesized acid-triggered LMNPs prepared by a simple sonicationmediated approach to achieve the effective release and enrichment of Dox near the nuclear membrane. This functional LMNP with an average diameter of 107 nm comprises an LM core and a thiolated polymeric shell where both MUA-CD and m-HA are embedded as ligands. As shown in Fig. 15A, after a Dox-loaded LMNP (LMNP/Dox-L) enters into the targeted cancer cell via endocytosis, a dynamic morphology fusion is triggered at acidic endosomes (pH=5) arising from the elimination of the oxidation film (Fig. 15B). One subsequent reaction induced by fusion is the dissociation of surface ligands from the LMNPs. Then, Dox embedded in ligands is released into the cytoplasm, leading to an increase in concentration of Dox around the nucleus. As a result, the probability of entering the cell nucleus will rise [26].
Evaluation through in vivo anticancer experiments further demonstrates that there is a noticeable difference in the volumes of tumours collected from mice treated with saline, Dox, LMNP/Dox (without targeting ligands) and LMNP/Dox-L at day 14, which demonstrates that

The HeLa tumour growth curves also indicate that there is no observable increase in tumour volume during treatment with LMNP/DoxL. In addition, there was no significant decrease in the body weight of the mice, indicating the low toxicity of the LMNPs (Fig. 15E).
4.1.1.2. Shape transformers to destroy endosome/lysosomes. Although anticancer drugs can achieve controllable enrichment via fusion of LMNPs, breaking through the limitation of lysosomal/endosomal membranes is still hard. In a recent attempt, Lu investigated a lighttriggered LMNP transformer (tNP) for realizing effective endosomal escape cargo delivery [24]. This transformer can be simply fabricated using a sonication technique to dispose of a centrifuge tube containing LMs and an aqueous solution of GQDs. Upon exposure to light, LMNPs coated with GQDs can efficiently absorb and convert near-infrared photon energy to generate heat and reactive oxygen species (ROS). Heat and ROS power the reaction between Ga and water (Ga+H2O → heat ROS (GaO)OH) and transform the shapes of the tNPs from spherical to rodlike nanostructures. This dramatic shape change could physically disrupt the endosomal membrane to facilitate endosomal escape of drug molecules (Fig. 16A). Moreover, another positive consequence is that ROS could remove liposomes by lipid oxidation [92], which also assist in the escape of drugs. Of note, toxicity from ROS to cells cannot be ignored. But, fortunately, LMNP transformers can consume toxic ROS to finish morphological transformation, which make ROS within an appropriate concentration range.
To verify the enhanced effect of light-triggered endosomal escape,
both Dox and bovine serum albumin are selected as model molecules. During an in vivo test, the endosomal membrane was fully punctured by tNP under light exposure, with noticeably changed morphology and increased volume, ensuring the escape of Dox and bovine serum albumin (Fig. 16B and C). Therefore, upon light irradiation, LMNPmediated spatiotemporal drug delivery shows great potential for inhibiting HeLa tumour growth. Eventually, tumours are completely eliminated on day 14, and there is no significant difference in body weight during treatment (Fig. 16D and E).
4.1.1.3. Effective sensitizers in photothermal therapy. Photothermal therapy, which deposits heat energy specifically in tumours, is an effective physical therapy against cancer, and the combination with chemotherapy could provide a valid way to inhibit drug resistance. To combine multiple therapies, Chechetka et al. investigated a multifunctional photothermal sensitizer comprising an LM core and double-functional layers [25].
To enhance the stability and solubility of LMNPs in an aqueous solvent, a functional layer containing DSPE-PEG2000-Amine and DC(8,9)PC is used to cover the surfaces of LMNPs via sonication for 10min, and functional LM nano-capsules (LMNCs) are formed with an average diameter of 110 nm (Fig. 17A). After reaching the laser irradiation spot, LMNCs aggregate immediately (Fig. 17B) and convert photon energy to thermal energy, which leads to a dramatic temperature rise from 20 ℃ to 34 ℃ at a laser power of 129 μW/μm2 (Fig. 17C). Concomitantly, ROS will be generated from energy and electron transfer [24]. Next, cancer cells may be eliminated in three ways: first, the generated ROS may destroy liposomes by lipid oxidation; second, the thermal energy absorbed from laser offers enough heat to kill the cancer cells; third, the aggregation of the LMNCs could cut off the nutrient supply of the tumour cells by physically sealing off the abnormal tumour blood vessels. To improve the targeted delivery ability of the LMNCs, the epidermal growth factor receptor antibody (anti-EGFR), a common tumour biomarker to target cancer cells, is coated on the surface of the LMNCs to form antibody-modified LM nanoparticles (anti-LMNCs) (Fig. 17D). In in vivo studies, both laser-irradiated LMNCs and anti-LMNCs express much better restriction efficacy towards tumour growth than those without laser irradiation after 13 days of treatment (Fig. 17E and F).
In addition, upon irradiation by NIR laser at a wide wavelength range (680–1170 nm), mice injected with anti-LMNCs and LMNCs show a strong photoacoustic (PA) signal in the tumour. The enhancement in PA signal in the anti-LMNC group is ˜33–103%, which is higher than that in the LMNC group (˜11–45%) (Fig. 17G). Notably, the corresponding PA signal linearly depends on the concentration of the antiLMNCs. sections.heading: 4.1.2. LMNPs as antibacterial biomaterial
sections.text:
Using a nanometal or nanometallic oxide, such as Ag [93], Cu/CuO [94,95], ZnO [96], to replace conventional antibiotics has become an effective way to inhibit bacterial growth. However, nanomaterials expressing superior antibacterial activity generally exhibit high toxicity for cells. To address this problem, Kurtjak et al. developed a
biocompatible nanocomposite (Ga@HAp) containing antibacterial nanospheres of Ga (16 wt%) and bioactive hydroxyapatite nanorods (HAp, 84 wt%) (Fig. 18A) [84]. Adding Ga@HAp to bacterial culture dishes could sharply decrease the number of bacterial cells (P. aeruginosa in
this case). In addition, a distinct change in the structure of the dead bacteria could be observed. For the dead bacteria exposed to Ga@HAp, many holes appeared in their cell wall, and the cytomembrane was completely ruptured. In contrast, the dead bacteria exposed to HAp
expressed only a decrease in cytomembrane or cell wall integrity (Fig. 18B). To verify the advanced antibacterial effect of Ga@HAp, silver nanocomposites that had already been proven to be effective against the growth of bacteria were selected as a negative control. The result indicates that the lowest concentration of Ga@HAp to inhibit the growth of bacteria is 0.1 g/L, which is lower than that of the silver nanocomposite (0.3 g/L) (Fig. 18C and D). In general, Ag could be deemed as one of the best inorganic antibacterial material. Therefore, a better performance of Ga nanoparticles indicates that LM may become a novel and efficient inorganic antibacterial material in the future.
Although Ga@HAp achieved superior bacteriostatic activity, the antibacterial mechanism is still unclear. The mainstream view is that Ga3+ ions released from nanoparticles can inhibit bacterial growth or kill the bacteria. Choi et al. synthesized six different types of Ga3+ ions and rifampin nanoparticles to inhibit the growth of virulent Mycobacterium tuberculosis [97]. Moreover, Ga3+ ion-based compounds also illustrated their potent inhibitory activity on the growth of both Mycobacteria and HIV in co-infected human macrophages [98]. Overall, there are a number of direct and indirect proofs suggesting the critical role of Ga3+ ions as an antimicrobial agent [99,100]. However, evidence obviously suggests that antibacterial activity is not just an outcome of the Ga3+ ions. As illustrated in Fig. 18E, two control groups having a similar concentration of Ga3+ ions with the Ga@HAp group show poor performance in inhibiting growth, especially the group of Ga3+ ions alone. In contrast, Ga@HAp performs satisfactorily after 30 h. An important factor, the surface roughness of the substrate, may have important influence on the lifecycle of the bacteria. Whether the addition of nanoparticles changes the surface roughness and further inhibits the growth of the bacteria is uncertain. Thus far, there does not exist a reasonable and systematic explanation for the antibacterial mechanism of Ga nanoparticles. What can be determined is the key role of Ga3+ ions, but whether Ga nanoparticles, Ga2O3 or other factors are also effective against bacterial growth should be further investigated.

sections.heading: 4.1.3. Toxicity of LMNPs
sections.text:
Although small doses of macroscopic LMs have been proven to be biocompatible, the toxicity of LMNPs remains controversial. However, there is increasing evidence showing that LMNPs could be safe biomaterials both in vitro and in vivo.
The toxicity effect of various nanoparticles was investigated in vitro. Lu et.al showed that LMNPs display low toxicity even at high concentrations (over 90% HeLa cells are alive at 1600 μg/ml) in contrast
to other rigid nanomaterials, such as single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), multi-walled CNTs (MWCNTs) and gold nanorods (Au-NRs) (Fig. 19A). Moreover, Wang et.al demonstrated that over 80% of human L-02 hepatocytes (L-02) are alive even at 300mg/L [101]. In vivo detection showed that high-concentration (up to 330mg/ml) LMNP injections had a negligible impact on the viability and body weight of mice up to 19 days (Fig. 19B) [25]. Furthermore, Lu et al. systematically evaluated the toxicity of LMNPs in mice, and none of the important indexes of liver function, including alanine aminotransferase, aspartate aminotransferase, alkaline phosphatase and albumin concentration, was affected by intravenous injection of LMNPs. Moreover, the urea levels in the blood of treated mice, an important indicator of kidney function, were also within the reference range (Fig. 19C–E). In addition, the authors also performed histology evaluation of the major organs (liver, spleen and kidney) and did not find noticeable organ damage (Fig. 19F). These results demonstrate the biocompatibility of LMNPs [26].
In fact, the mechanism that explains why LMNPs show low toxicity for biological bodies remains elusive but appears to be strongly related to the following factors. One is that the LMNPs can be gradually degraded when exposed to an acidic environment. In other words, a number of LMNPs in the cells will transform from Ga into Ga3+ ions in acidic lysosomes/endosomes, which naturally possess slightly acidity and have a pH of 5. Interestingly, the main degradation product, Ga3+ ion, has not only been reported to reverse drug resistance in drug-resistant cancer cells but is also a main component of FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of hypercalcemia of malignancy. The other factor is that residual LMNPs (perhaps the majority) can be removed through both faecal and renal excretions. The monitoring test for excretion indicates that the excreted concentrations of both Ga and In steadily decreased over time [26].
Taken together, the systematic evaluation of LMNP toxicity has not yet been established, but there is increasing evidence suggesting that LMNPs could be ideal theranostic biomaterials.

sections.heading: 4.2.1. The pattern mechanism in LMP-enabled electronics
sections.text:
To meet the requirements of emerging applications such as wearable sensing, soft co-robotics and physical human-machine interaction, flexible and stretchable electronics have recently drawn extensive attention because they can maintain their function under great
deformation [102]. As new emerging materials, intrinsically soft LMs have been introduced to the manufacture of various electronics due to their superior properties, such as high electrical conductivity, high deformability, and high chemical stability [43]. There exist several methods utilizing LM inks to create printed electronics, such as direct writing, mask-based printing and spray printing [45,103]. However, the large-scale use of LMs in electronics remains difficult; for example, the high surface tension of bulk LMs (> 400mN/m) [6] restricts direct patterning through straightforward technologies such as stencil and ink-jet printing [49,104], and high LM consumption (the thickness of the LM pattern is usually more than 100 μm) impedes the application to the mass manufacturing of practical circuits. In contrast, the utilization of LMP benefits addresses such problems. However, LMPs are not perfectly conductive due to the oxide layer on the particles. Initially, the Kramer group proposed a concept called “mechanical sintering” to wipe off such a layer on the surface in which a pinpoint was used to rupture particles to merge together, thus obtaining conductive pathways [46]. The mechanical sintering method enables patterned traces of LMPs with high conductive performance without a significant input of energy required by thermal sintering [105] and specialized crafts dispensable in photonic sintering [106], flash sintering [107,108] and laser sintering [109]. According to this mechanism, using a bottom-up approach to fabricate LM-based circuits is an appropriate way to increase the resolution of patterned traces.
Some researchers have reported their use of sonication to create LMPs with tuneable particle sizes and sinter them to change their electrical properties from nonconductive to conductive. There are mainly two approaches to enable electric conductivity conversion functionality: one is to deposit a layer of particles on the surface of the elastomer and use a tip to directly exert pressure (Fig. 20A); the other is to inject the particle-organic suspension into microfluidic channels followed by organic solvent evaporation and mechanical sintering (Fig. 20B). Sintering stresses are carried out and measured by the experimental facility shown in Fig. 20C. However, conductive patterns fabricated with the former method cannot suffer from large deformations, such as stretching, in practical applications because the applied stress will also sinter conductive patterns in undesirable regions, leading to short circuits in electronics. In addition, it is also difficult to
fabricate complicated microstructures to pattern functional circuits because this approach requires the microfluidic channels to be continuous from beginning to end. To solve these problems, a strategy involving casting and peeling off polymers from patterned LM circuits was introduced to form surface-embedded metals in polymeric hosts (Fig. 20D). This strategy utilized stress during stripping (calculated as 4500MPa), which is much larger than the yield stress of Ga oxide (approximately 300MPa) to effectively break the oxide layer of LMPs embedded in elastomers and release the inner LM core to coalesce into conductive pathways [60]. This strategy successfully avoided undesirable sintering of LMPs during deformations because the initial nonconductive parts made out of un-sintered particles were replaced by insulating elastomer substrates.
Furthermore, to reduce the high consumption of LMPs in patterning circuits, which inhibits their further applications, a recyclable circuit based on the reversible conversion from particles to conductive wires was fabricated on paper using mechanical methods including mechanical sintering and sonication [110]. After the desired LM circuits obtained by selective mechanical sintering fulfilled their missions, valuable LM inks on paper were designed to be reused by transferring bulk LM (circuits) back into the LMPs in an alcohol solvent with sonication as illustrated in Fig. 20E. In this way, LM-based circuits could be readily recycled, and the reborn circuits showed nearly the same electrical stability under deformation as pristine circuits.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Circuits fabricated with LMPs
sections.text:
Compared with the traditional circuit fabrication approach, LMprinted electronic technology could simplify the manufacturing process and greatly increase efficiency. Conductive wires are the fundamental constituent elements of functional LM-based electronics. Several methods, such as direct printing [104], screen printing [111], and spray printing [112,113], have been reported utilizing LM-based inks with modified wettability and high electrical conductivity to manufacture flexible printed electronics. For example, Zheng et al. invented the world’s first automatic LM printer using a direct printing method to pattern bulk LM via tapping [104]. This printing technology requires LM to be pre-oxidized to increase adhesion between the LM and the substrate to resist large surface tension. To skip the pre-oxidized
procedure and improve the resolution of circuits fabricated with bulk LM inks, spray printing and screen printing were introduced to create thinner electrical wires [111,113]. As shown in Fig. 21A and B, both of these methods utilize an airbrush, a mask/screen and a substrate that are adopted for the atomized printing system.
The mechanism of these printing approaches can be illustrated as placing some pressure introduced by airflow forces on the LM inks located in the airbrush and turning the inks into atomized microparticles, followed by patterning them via a pre-designed mask/screen. The rapid oxidation of atomized LMMPs due to their large specific surface area guarantees adhesion between the deposition layer of the ink and the substrate. However, the resolution of printed electronics is limited by the dimensions of the tools (a mask or a screen mesh) required in the present methods.
In addition, resolution (also represented by the minimum conductive line width) is also determined by the size of the particles utilized in the printing process. To further increase patterning resolution, efforts have been made to combine the ink jetting method with smaller LMPs. According to this preparation method, high-resolution conductive pathways, soft circuit boards, microelectrodes, interconnects, antennas, biosensors and other electronic components composed of LMPs could be easily mounted. Boley et al. created EGaIn nanoparticles
via sonication and thiol self-assembly, followed by inkjet printing and then mechanically sinter-dispersed nanoparticles [46]. Fig. 22A represents the potential to fabricate circuits with high stretchability and high integration via this method. It has been proven that mechanical sintering can be used to form minimum conductive traces of ˜1 μm wide, which are half the size of previously reported features (Fig. 22B). To ensure the functionality of LMP-based circuits, an “NC” (abbreviation for North Carolina) soft circuit board with LEDs was fabricated and lighted. In addition, LMPs also showed the feasibility of binding rigid components to soft circuit boards as interconnects without soldering (Fig. 22C). As shown in Fig. 22D and E, an antenna injected in the microchannel followed by a mechanical sintering step was proven to be frequency-tuneable (shifted from 16 to 1.8 GHz) by elongating conductive traces (from 0 to 165mm). Furthermore, Mohammed et al. developed an automated multimode printing process, which endowed the manufacturing process with mass production capability, repeatability and scalability for complex flexible and stretchable electronics [114]. Circuits patterned using this process have the same order of magnitude of resistance for devices with similar dimensions that use bulk liquid metal as the conductive material. This automated printing mode not only ensures printing of complicated and functional circuit boards but also allows for the fabrication of wearable sensors with great
robustness, stretchability and flexibility based on the LM resistancepressure response. The underlying mechanism is that the resistance of the continuous trace is determined by the minimum width of that trace, which can be altered by implementing different pressures. Using this mechanism, a strain and pressure sensor was printed, as shown in Fig. 22F, to demonstrate wearable sensing ability by its measured output resistance as a function of pressure applied by a finger.
Conductive patterns fabricated by the combined inkjet printing and mechanically sintering method cannot bear large deformations, which may cause undesirable sintering. In addition, a tip is necessary to sinter the LMPs to obtain conductive wires. In some cases, the size of the marker also limits the resolution of subsequent circuits. Moreover, a deposition layer of LM particles is also requisite, thus resulting in a low utilization rate of particles with this technique. Without a marker or a nozzle, a peeling-off technique was proposed to pattern micro-circuits with high resolution (15 μm). Conductors made in this way were used to fabricate stretchable circuits and a wearable glove keyboard, as shown in Fig. 23. The resolutions of different fabrication methods to pattern electronics circuits are summarized in Table 3.
In addition to those with planar two-dimensional soft electronics, microfluidic devices with patterned three-dimensional (3D) microstructures are also important in a variety of newly emerging fields owing to the enhanced efficiency and reliability of their
microfabricated systems. However, conventional 3D printing technologies are mainly used for the manufacture of non-functional structures rather than useful microfluidic components. With the help of a thin shell of oxide layer composed of gallium oxide, LM retains a stable nonequilibrium state when patterned. There still remain disadvantages such as labour intensive, geometry limiting, and not readily scalable to automated high-volume manufacturing in microfabrication [103]. Efforts have been paid to improve the fabrication technique of applied microstructures. For instance, to remove the limitations of large dimension and low aspect ratio, Tang et al. proposed a method to create 3D microstructures using dielectrophoresis [47]. First, the LMPs were fixed upon planar gold microelectrode pads. Then, an alkaline solution was used to coalesce the microparticles. Finally, an LM microstructure was obtained after applying a high flow rate to wash out excess particles (Fig. 24A). Such microstructures showed better capacity for trapping suspended nanoparticles when compared with that of planar microelectrodes (Fig. 24B). In addition, by placing the 3D microstructures near a hot spot, these structures served as micro-fins and demonstrated better performance to improve convective heat transfer compared to those without such LM microstructure (Fig. 24C).

sections.heading: 4.2.3. LMP-enabled composite elastomer conductors
sections.text:
Wearable electronics are supposed to be soft enough to provide
intact connection between the human body and functional components. Soft robots are defined as robots that are made almost entirely up of soft and non-rigid materials such as elastomers, rubbers, polymers, gels and even fluids instead of hard plastics, rigid metals or brittle
semiconductors. Soft materials are highly regarded because robots or electric devices incorporate with humans should possess certain properties including elastic, robust and rheological properties of materials used and must be compatible with natural human skin [115].
Ideal materials used in the field of wearable electronics should not only be safe (also called biocompatible) but also ensure the ability to move freely and work properly. However, there always exists a tradeoff between elastic deformation ability and electronic functionality, which is the major hurdle constraining the applications of current materials engineered for wearable devices and robotics. This problem could be addressed when mixing the elastic substrate with inclusions integrated with high deformability and electricity. Until now, a common approach to prepare functional materials used for soft and stretchable wearable electronics has been to embed thin films of elastomers with a percolation network of conductive particulates, such as structured carbon black, carbon nanotubes, silver nanoparticles, silver
nanowires or graphene. However, as shown in Fig. 25A, the volumetric conductivity of these materials is relatively low compared with that of integral conductors, whereas improving conductivity by increasing the weight percentage of conductive filler increases the mechanical stiffness and brittleness of the composite. As a conductive filler, LMPs represent an ideal alternative to rigid particles that increase volumetric conductivity through percolation compared to that of a non-conducting elastomer without increasing the stiffness and brittleness of the subsequent composite, as evidenced by a similar modulus. In contrast, functional LM-based materials with low melting points could be blended with soft materials to form soft conductors with high conductivity, great stretchability and reconfigurability. Although this type of composite is not initially conductive, modified composites can be rendered conductive by casting pressure on them to activate the mechanical sintering of percolating particles (Fig. 25C).
