sections.heading: 4.2.4. Self-healing materials based on LMPs
sections.text:
LM is an outstanding candidate among all self-healing materials due to its favourable properties, including good fluidity, high surface tension and high electrical conductivity.
The self-healable feature is crucial in the manufacture of rechargeable cells filled with nickel-cadmium, nickel-metal hydride or lithiumion inclusions [118]. Among them, lithium-ion battery (LIB) is believed to be one of the most promising power sources, covering almost all domains of energy supply, including portable electronics, rechargeable vehicles and even large-scale energy recovery [119]. The increasing demands on energy supply continue to drive improvements in the capacity and cycling stability of LIB. However, LIB with both superior specific capacity and cycle performance remains elusive due to the mechanical fracture caused by volume expansion and contraction cycle through lithiation and de-lithiation processes. Several methods have been proposed to enhance inferior cycle performance, including adding inactive elements or buffer components and building nanostructured electrodes, whereas the incompatibility between the pursuit of high capacity and the elongation of lifespan has not yet been eliminated.
According to the latest reports, self-healing polymer-mediated LIB enables slim geometry and simple packing during the cycles at the expense of higher cost per watt/hour (w/h). Mixing Li-active materials with inactive elements and buffer components can improve cycle performance but somehow suppresses the increase in specific capacity [44].
Compared with the aforementioned approaches, the utilization of highly deformable LM materials could be a more effective solution to address the problem of cycle performance, as illustrated in Fig. 26A. Considering that Sn has a higher specific capacity (993mA h/g) than Ga (7209mA h/g), Sn could probably enhance the capacity of the Ga-based anode, a new structure composed of GaSn LM alloy nanoparticles supported by a reduced graphene oxide (RGO)/carbon nanotube (CNT) that was fabricated as a room-temperature anode for LIBs. GaSn alloy nanoparticles with diameters ranging from 50 to 500 nm stabilized in the carbon skeleton formed a three-dimensional structure to attenuate the volume change caused by the reversible lithiation and de-lithiation cycles. There was no obvious crack formation due to the self-healing properties of the liquid-state material during the integral process of
charge and discharge, as shown in Fig. 26B. This new anode was reported with superior capacity (775mA h/g at 200mA/g) and stable cycling performance (retaining nearly 100% capacity within 4000 cycles).
It is well known that circuit components are developing towards higher integration and further shrinkage; as a result, there has been an increasingly heavier demand on electronic devices with higher input/ output (I/O) current densities and smaller feature sizes. However, the durability of such electronic components is limited by the failure of conductive pathways due to poor thermal management and severe mechanical damage [120]. Nevertheless, the fabrication of self-healable materials that can repair both mechanically and electrically under severe damage still faces great challenges, including appropriate softness/ stiffness, high temperature tolerance, function decline and manual intervention requirements. To overcome the fragility of conductive pathways in highly integrated circuits, Palleau et al. introduced a healing electrical wire that could be fabricated by micro-injecting EGaIn into a healable polymer to reconnect a simple electronic circuit, as evidenced by the light emitting phenomenon of a pair of LEDs
mentioned in reference [18]. Compared with conventional healing approaches, this method shows high efficiency and simple manipulation without external intervention. In the microscale, LMMPs covered with urea formaldehyde with a mean diameter of 10 μm, as indicated in Fig. 27A, were utilized to restore conductivity in a broken circuit by the release of conductive microcapsule inclusions to the damage site (Fig. 27B, C).
To monitor the reconfiguration effect of such circuits, Blaiszik et al. used a Wheatstone bridge on the specimen serving as a bridge arm to track the change in voltage, indicating rapid electrical recovery from 0 to 99% in 20 μs, demonstrating great contrast with a control specimen without LM inclusions showing no observable recovery, and how the healing efficiency is influenced by the filling fraction of microcapsules (Fig. 27D,E) [88]. Optimized particle size and homogeneity of such containers encapsulating LMMPs with a polymer were synthesized via in situ polymerization, and a smart passivation film was prepared at the same time. Cutting- or pressing-induced ruptured LMMP capsules (Fig. 27F) were released and then transported LM flow to the broken area, leading to effective recovery of electrical pathways. With the utilization of this type of material, both the reliability and durability in perovskite solar cells could be improved (Fig. 27G). As shown in Fig. 27H, the electrical pathways were almost entirely recovered, as
shown by the negligible increase in resistance from 0.82 Ω to 1.421 Ω (without this passivation layer, the value increased significantly to 1.213×1010 Ω after cutting) and exhibited a power conversion efficiency (PCE) retention of 99% compared with the initial value (PCE=15.021%) (Fig. 27I) [121].
Although soft materials (elastomers, polyelectrolyte gels and liquid metals) have superior elastic compliance and deformability, they are vulnerable to tearing, puncturing or other mechanical damage that could cause electrical failure. Markvicka et al. introduced a material architecture composed of LMPs suspended in a soft elastomer (Fig. 28A) [122]. The mechanism lies in that the LMMPs around the broken sites tend to bind with neighbours in situ at the moment of damage (Fig. 28B), thus reconfiguring the conductive pathways and transmitting electrical signals without interruption under mechanical damage. Otherwise, the robustness as a main factor of functional circuits was also proven by repeatedly breaking a self-repairing digital counter. As shown in Fig. 28C and D, a minimal increase in absolute resistance (< 1 Ω) was recorded after enduring subsequent cuts or punches. More importantly, such material could retain stable electrical conductivity during or after damage occurs.

sections.heading: 4.3. LMPs in thermal management
sections.text:
The inherent high thermal conductivity and adjustable electric conduction make LMPs suitable for TIMs. Meanwhile, softness and transformability facilitate better coupling between the LMPs and conventional materials. Hence, LMPs are becoming increasingly important components in TIMs.
LMMPs or LMNPs are usually used as soft inclusions to fabricate high-performance TIMs. Compared to solid particle fillers, LM particles create a dramatic adaption, especially with soft substrates, which could avoid internal stress concentrations and bulk rigidity.
Soft and transformable LMMPs, as filling materials, impart high thermal conductivity to both thermal grease and silicone elastomer. Although thermal grease possesses great thermal stability and wettability that benefit electronic packaging, the intrinsically poor thermal conductivity always restricts its application. To address this problem, Mei et al. blended LMs and thermal grease in air to construct a heat transfer path inside the composite material (Fig. 29A and B). As a result, thermal conductivity and volume resistivity were optimized up to 5.37W/ (m ∙ K) and 1.07 × 107 Ω ∙ m, respectively (Fig. 29C). If currently commercialized thermal grease is based on metal particle inclusions as a standard, which usually has thermal conductivity of no
more than 7W/ (m·K), LMP-composited grease demonstrates strong competitiveness. It should be noted that composite TIM has almost no corrosion effect because thermal grease will avoid direct contact to decrease the possibility of reaction between LMs and electronic products [21]. Superior to conventional solid fillers, LMMP fillers could deform and stretch along with soft dielectric materials. By dispersing LMMPs into an silicone elastomer, Bartlett et al. obtained an elastomeric pad with extreme deformations and metal-like thermal conductivity (Fig. 29D). The thermal conductivity of this liquid-metalembedded elastomer (LMEE) increased in the deformation direction and finally reached 9.8 ± 0.8W/ (m·K) at 400% strain (Fig. 29E–G), which may be because single micro-LM particles were in contact with adjacent particles during stretching and thus created rapid thermal transport (Fig. 29A). In addition, the modulus was 89 ± 3 KPa after 300% pre-strain, and the highest strain limit was over 600% (Fig. 29H), which helped break the restriction for applications that require materials with both high thermal conductivity and low mechanical stiffness (Fig. 29I) [62].
To obtain a more continuous structure and further optimize the performance of electrical insulations, LMs have been fabricated at the nanoscale and added into polymers. For example, a nano-liquid metal thermal grease that has high thermal conductivity and is electrically
insulating (nLM-THEMs) was introduced (Fig. 30A and B). The volume resistivity of such composite is 3.09× 109 Ωm at 330 V, and the maximum thermal conductivity is up to 6.73 ± 0.04W/(m K) (˜50 times more than that of the base polymer) (Fig. 30C).
Notably, nLM-THEMs demonstrate much better performance than micro-LM thermal grease composites fabricated by the same principle in both thermal conductivity and volume resistivity [89]. This may be because nanoparticles ensure a more continuous heat transfer path; additionally, the oxide layer of the nanoparticles could cut off the electronic transfer pathway between single particles. Moreover, similar to the micro-LM composite, nLM-THEMs also have no corrosion effect due to the shield layer of thermal grease (Fig. 30D). In addition, LMNPs have been used in thermal tapes [123]. Owing to the properties of indium, the shear strength, mechanical performance and stable heat performance of nano-TIMs are enhanced. Overall, not only LMMPs but also LMNPs contribute to the optimization of conventional TIMs. To better improve the performance of the TIMs, future investigations of micro/nano-LMs should be focused on.

sections.heading: 4.4. Soft and transformable LMPs motors
sections.text:
So far, much work has been done on bulk LM motors, and LM is considered the ideal material for soft robots in the future because of its inherent softness and transformability [72,73,124,125]. However, bulk LMs cannot function in some narrow environments and do not show high degradability in contrast to LMMPs and LMNPs, which all limit their applications. Therefore, it is urgent to develop tiny LM motors (TLMM) that are soft and transformable to adapt to complex environments such as blood vessels and the tumour microenvironment.
In 2012, Gao et al. designed a type of Al-powered micromotor (Motor 1), which is propelled by abundant H2 bubbles that stem from the drastic reaction between Al and water (2Al+6H2O→2Al (OH)3+3H2) [126]. This type of TLMM is composed of a Ga-Al core and a half-side titanium layer. The thin titanium layer could hinder the reaction between Al and water, while the other hemisphere without a titanium layer is directly exposed to water and generates a strong bubble-propelling force (F1) to push motors forward (Fig. 31A and B). Motor 1 could realize a rapid motion in pure water where micromotors swim at a speed of 3mm/s (over 150 body lengths per second).
Importantly, biological environments such as phosphate-buffered saline, human serum and cell culture media are also suitable for achieving the performance of these micromotors (Fig. 31C) and provide a platform for microrobots at work as a targeting drug delivery system. However, such TLMMs can only realize planar locomotion via swimming in the solution. In 2016, Tang found that contacting nickel particles to LMMPs in NaOH solution would induce LMMPs to jump or roll on different substrates (Motor 2), which achieved three-dimensional motion. This is because the point contact between LMNPs and nickel particles in the electrolyte will lead to the electron discharge effect, which can further induce drastic H2 generation and finally generate F1 (Fig. 31D). H2 bubbles tend to adhere to hydrophobic substrates and escape from hydrophilic ones. Thus, the bubbles aggregating on the hydrophobic polypropylene (PP) substrate will induce intermittent jumping of the LMMPs. In contrast, rolling rather than jumping can be observed on the hydrophilic quartz substrate (Fig. 31E and F). However, this type of motor suffers from low speed because H2, the source of the propelling force, mainly stems from a weak electron discharge effect [90].
The self-powered motors listed above adopt F1 from H2 bubbles as
the driving force to overcome flow resistance and frictional force. They can carry out a simple movement in alkaline or aqueous solutions. However, it is impossible for them to control their direction, speed and region because of the unordered and uncontrollable process of generating H2. Thus far, controlling the motion of TLMMs can only be realized in NaOH solution in the presence of an external electric field or magnetic field. The principle will be detailed below.
Generally, Ga will react spontaneously with the NaOH solution. This reaction could produce gallates such as [Ga(OH)4]−, which make the surface of LMMPs negatively charged. Then, those negative charges will attempt to attract positive ions of the solution and lead to the establishment of a diffuse layer—electrical double layer (EDL), which is a critical element to realize the controllable movement of TLMM (Fig. 32A). If an electric field is applied, a TLMM driven by an electric field force (F2) will move to the positive electrode. Meanwhile, the distribution of surface charges is also altered, which has an impact on surface tension and further influences the movement of TLMMs. This process can be interpreted as follows: according to Lippman’s equation,

The value of γ is determined by that of V because γ0 and c are constant. Thus, surface tension will be asymmetrical if charges are unevenly distributed on the surface of the motors. Surface tension is closely related to the shape of the LMMPs. Hence, as shown in Fig. 32A, the shape of the TLMM will be remodelled, and the radius of the right hemisphere will increase. According to the Young–Laplace equation, P= γ ∙ (2/r) (P is the pressure, r is the radius curvature), a pressure difference within the droplet will occur, which provides a weak force (F3) to push motors forward. Except for the external electric field, adding Al to LM will also affect the distribution of charges on the surface. This is because LMs and Al will form a short-circuited battery where the Al electrode gathers a mass of negative charges. In 2015, Tan
and Yuan used an electrical method to control the direction and velocity of motion of Al-powered motors for the first time (Motor 3) [91]. As shown in Fig. 32B, the motion of the motors transforms from random movement (right side) into specific movement towards the anode (left side) after an external electric field is applied. In addition, the speed of the motors could easily reach a high level of 43 cm/s under 20 V.
Similar to the electric field, the magnetic field also influences the motion of the TLMMs. The Al-powered motor is an example. As mentioned above, the Al electrode will gather many negative charges, subsequently, numerous H2 bubbles will emit from the Al electrode and propel motors forward. Hence, the direction of motion of the motors is mainly determined by the site where a mass of negative charges exists. According to the Lorentz force formula, =F QvB (where Q is the value of charge, v is the speed of charge, and B is magnetic field intensity), those negative charges will be exerted by the Lorentz force, and the site
that is filled with negative charges will be altered. As a result, the continuous motion of the TLMMs may be influenced and even interrupted because F1 does not have a fixed direction (Fig. 32C and D). Based on this phenomenon, Tan and Gui designed a magnetic trap to confine the motion domain of motors (Motor 4) [127]. In general, most motors will move along the boundary of the permanent magnet, with some towards the interior. However, as shown in Fig. 32E, a few motors can cross the boundary because the Lorentz force is strong enough to change the direction of F1 of the motors that attempt to enter the interior.
The four types of TLMMs listed above are mainly driven by F1 and realize a controllable movement with the assistance of F2 and F3. However, H2, the main by-product during movement, is not a harmless gas, hindering the application on biosystem. Recently, Wang et.al proposed a type of rod-like and innocuous TLMMs (Motor 5) of which the dimeter range from 400 nm to ˜6 μm (Fig. 33A) [101]. Different from the four types of motors that are all self-powered, Motor 5 could realize rotation and translation only in the presence of an acoustic field that could generate a primary radiation force (F4). The F4 acting on motors in the Z direction balances the gravitational force, which makes
motors float in a levitation plane. Meanwhile, the F4 in the XY plane induces the rotation of motors that could push them forward. This is because the two ends of Motor 5 are different in size and such asymmetric shape leads to the unbalance of F4 (Fig. 33B). When the frequency of the applied ultrasound field is 420 KHz, the velocity of the motors with a diameter of 400 nm could reach a high speed at 23 μm/s (Fig. 33C). Owing to their low toxicity, softness, transformation and outstanding capacity on moving, Motor 5 could achieve an ideal performance in biomedical applications. As is shown in Fig. 33D and E, motors had approached and entered into the predefined cell, and finally realized the intracellular localization. Notably, the merging between motors, an important phenomenon that has been proved on bulk motors, will happen after the oxidation film covering on the surface of motors is dissolved in endosome.
In summary, TLMMs are not only soft and transformable but also capable of reaching a high speed, and can easily speed up, stop the motors or control their moving directions. However, much of the performance needs to be optimized and improved. For example, the motors can only achieve controllable movement in an alkaline solution in the presence of an external electric or magnetic field. Moreover, some
properties that have been demonstrated in bulk LM motors, such as reversible merging and separating, have not been fully disclosed on micro/nano-motors. Overall, TLMMs should be further investigated. Expecting to help researchers better understand the status of TLMMs, we will detail the five types of motors (Motor 1–5) described above in Table 4.

sections.heading: 4.5. Summary on size-dependent characteristics and applications
sections.text:
Small size effects on the properties of electricity, magnetism, acoustics, optics and thermodynamics are induced as the size decrease from microscale to nanoscale, which make LMPs suitable for different fields. In the above sections, we have introduced the practical applications of LMPs in biomedicine, soft electronics, thermal management, soft and transformable motors. Thus, microscale LMs based motors could be pushed or regulated by controlling the distribution of EDL. However, as the diameter further decreases to nanoscale, the ability of EDL to regulate motion is diminished [101]. Therefore, the LM nanorod motors realize rotation and translation by utilizing the energy from acoustic field instead of EDL. Another important difference between LMMPs and LMNPs is that LMMPs are more susceptible to deformation under tensile loading, which makes LMMPs suitable for stretchable and soft TIMs [62]. Besides, self-healing LMMPs are desirable for efficiently repairing broken wires and improving the cycle life of battery [44]. LMMPs, rather than LMNPs, respond better to wire damage and easily repair the broken wire [121]. Compared to LMMPs, LMNPs need the protection from surfactants to keep stability and avoid aggregation. Fortunately, some insulative surfactants layer coating on the surface of particles have a negligible influence on heat transfer but broke the electronic transmission path of electrons. Therefore, those insulative LMNPs could be a promising candidate for soft and insulative TIMs [89]. Besides, LMNPs with diameter of ˜100 nm or less are more suitable for anticancer because those LMNPs easily aggregate on the tumor site owing to EPR effect. Then, LMNPs can effectively enter cancer cell and release drugs to kill them [26]. Importantly, part of LMNPs could realize a dramatic shape change from sphere to rod-like to puncture endosomes [24]. Overall, the size is closely related to the characters of LMPs and size-dependent characteristics are significant for exploring the applications of LMPs.

sections.heading: 5. Future outlook
sections.text: As surveyed above, functional LMPs have been applied in biomedicine, soft electronics, self-healing materials and small motors. In addition, LMPs could also be alternative materials for bioimaging, vascular nanorobots and TIMs. Moreover, there are still many challenges that be addressed urgently.

sections.heading: 5.1. Potential of LMPs in bioimaging and vascular nanorobots applications
sections.text:
Bulk LM has been applied to angiography, which depicts a clearer capillary image than conventional iohexol images [9]. Recently, Lu et al. utilized LMNPs for X-ray imaging and claimed that X-ray signals will be enhanced by the assembling of nanoparticles into large precipitates [24]. Similarly, functional LMNPs that have stronger PA intensity over an extensive wavelength range were also demonstrated [25]. What’s more, the potential applications of LMPs in medicine go far beyond bioimaging, LMPs are also attractive as vascular nanorobots. When coupled with magnetic materials, LMNPs can move towards a particular direction and assemble on the targeted location. LMNPs may therefore be a suitable tool for controllable vascular embolization used for bronchial artery embolization to treat haemoptysis, renal artery embolization or cancer treatment [86]. Importantly, based on the fact
that the surface of the LMNPs could carry controllable drugs and couple different types of bioactive substances, more efficient targeted drug delivery can be realized. Magnetic LMPs aggregated around the tumour site could seal off blood tissue to cut off the nutrient supply and keep higher drug concentrations in the tumour tissue by controlling release [128–130].
5.2. Taking full use of stable and phase-change LMPs in energy field
The phase-change LMPs with a specific melting point can be obtained by adjusting the ratio of Ga, In and Sn and controlling the size of particles. Thus, LMPs are valuable as phase-change TIMs. Liu et al. proposed a phase-change solder consisting of Cu and In micro-powders [131]. However, this solder is restricted by unstable heat performance, and its absorbed energy decreases rapidly with increasing thermal cycling due to the decline of latent heat. Recent studies have shown that Ga nanoparticles can maintain stability after several thermal cycles [58,64], indicating the excellent reversibility of phase transition for LMNPs. In addition, DSC results illustrate that there is no wide disparity in latent heat between Ga nanoparticles and bulk Ga that has been used as a phase-change material [19,64], demonstrating that the latent heat of Ga nanoparticles is enough to meet the demand of energy management. Overall, with further exploration, LMNPs will frequently emerge in practical applications in relevant fields.

sections.heading: 5.3. Developing effective fabrication methods of several nanometer LMNPs
sections.text:
When the nanoparticle size approaches the wavelength of light and De Broglie wave, small size effects on the properties of electricity, magnetism, acoustics, optics and thermodynamics are induced. LMNPs that are soft and transformable may express different effects in contrast to other rigid nanoparticles. However, the basic researches that could be deemed as guideline for these unique effects are still scarce. Similarly, there are few studies attempting to explore the corresponding quantum benefit of LMs. One important reason for those flaws is that LMNPs have not received enough attention in contrast to other rigid metal nanoparticles such as gold and Cu nanoparticles etc. According to the data from web of science (Table 1), researches of LMNPs on TIMs, drug delivery, medical devices etc. are rare in the past five years. The other is closely related to the fabrication technique of LMNPs. LMNPs can keep long-term stability only in solution in the presence of a surfactant layer that is covered on the surface. Even worse, the exogenous layer has a crucial impact on the intrinsic property of LMNPs, and makes it impossible to explore the inherent properties of LMNPs.
Although numerous fabrication methods have been introduced in section 3, only PVD can produce particles that can maintain stability and dispersion in the absence of surfactants. As a new member of tiny particles family, LMNPs cannot get rid of the defects of tiny particles themselves, such as particle deposition, susceptibility to fouling. Besides, LNMPs is liquid-state metallic particles and easy to fuse in the absence of oxidation film, which make it hard to further decrease the
mean size of LMNPs. To solve these problems listed above, some attempts should be explored urgently, such as improving the nanomaterials surface properties, searching for the optimal dispersing agents and stabilizers as well as researching the anti-fusion methods. It should be noted that the existing technique to fabricate LMNPs concentrates on physical principle while some chemistry methods that are efficient on the fabrication of rigid nanoparticles are completely ignored. Chemistry methods may provide a new platform to efficiently simplify the production method, reasonably decrease and steadily uniform the particle size in the future.

sections.heading: 5.4. Investigating biocompatibility and toxicity of LMNPs systematically
sections.text:
The toxicity, an important factor for biological materials, isn’t assessed systematically for LMMPs so far. As mentioned in 4.1.3, although Lu et al. and Wang et.al have confirmed that a number of Ga nanoparticles in cells will finish a transformation from Ga into Ga3+ ion in acidic environment, how to clear residual LMNPs (perhaps the majority) in the body hasn’t been explored in detail. Numerous in vivo results indicated that the primary target organs and distribution sites for nanoparticles exposure are the lung, liver and kidney [132]. For example, alveolar macrophages have capability to clear nanoparticles larger than 100 nm via endocytosis. Kidney could achieve the clearance function by glomerular filtration, tubular secretion, and tubular reabsorption. But those basic functions have not been proved on LMNPs, and only a few evidences indicated that LMNPs can be removed through both fecal and renal excretions. Besides, the toxicity that are dependent on the shape of nanoparticles has also been neglected. Numerous evidences stated that the size, shape even the aspect ratio of nanoparticles have strong impact on circulation of nanoparticles in bloodstream [133,134]. However, the current researches for LMNPs only focus on spherical and rod-shaped LMNPs. Obviously, the fact that LMNPs are liquid state and high compliance has been ignored.
Overall, as an emerging material, many potential applications need to be investigated in depth. In the meantime, a mass of severe challenges should be solved eagerly.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, fabrication methods, typical features, various applications and scientific challenges have been systematically reviewed for recently emerging transformable soft liquid metal micro/nanomaterials. Stable LMPs could be obtained via adding surfactants and using facile techniques such as SLICE and sonication. These tiny particles, as metal particles, are endowed with superior thermal and electrical conductivities that meet the basic requirements for printed electronics and thermal management. More importantly, numerous unique capacities different from those of conventional metals are expressed, including transformable, soft, and self-healing. Such uniqueness increases the odds that the addition of LMPs may overcome the conventional bottlenecks existing in the above practical applications and broaden their utilization into biomedicine areas such as antibacterial and anticancer treatment. In anticancer therapy, functional LMPs with shape transformers and photothermal effects have been utilized in carriers for controllable drug delivery, endosome/lysosome destruction and combined thermal therapy. In soft electronics, when the intrinsically soft bulk LM transforms into LMPs, the troublesome mismatch between high surface tension and inkjet printing will be eliminated. In terms of selfhealing, the incompatibility between capacity and lifespan induced by mechanical fracture could be addressed by the addition of LMMPs. That is to say, self-healing particles will protect conductive units from cracking and help retain their continuous structure. In addition, the function of a thin oxide layer ensures that highly electrically insulating TIM will be outstanding when the particle diameter reaches tens of nanometres in scale. Using a small amount of LMs generally obtains a tremendous effect, which increases the odds of extensive exploration in
different areas in the coming years. Overall, LMPs play an increasing role in many applications and will provide a fertile ground for future discoveries and developments.

metadata.abstractText: Liquid metal is a liquid-state metallic material with a low melting point at or around room temperature. Owing to their high thermal or electrical conductivity, low viscosity and superior fluidity, liquid metals are emerging as a highly desirable candidate in a broad array of areas, such as flexible electronics, thermal management, soft machines and biomedical materials. However, bulk liquid metal is not readily utilized because of its high surface tension and large dimension-induced dexterity limitations. To address this challenge, liquid metals have been innovated with micro/nanotechnology to endow the bulk liquid metals with remarkably diversified performances. These new functional materials not only possess the softness of classical liquid metals but also have many outstanding properties, including great thermal conductivity, self-healing ability and stimuli-responsive deformability. Compared to rigid inorganic micro/nanoscale materials, soft liquid metal micro/nanoparticles demonstrate their unconventionally superior flexibility, compliance and tunability. This review is dedicated to summarize the state-of-the-art progress in fabricating methods, highlight unique features, and discuss applications of liquid metal micro/nanoparticles in biomedicine, soft electronics, thermal management and soft motors. Future outlooks, including both opportunities and scientific challenges of liquid metal micro/nanoparticles, are also presented here.
